title: Exception when client requests 'attestation' events
body:

### Steps to Reproduce (Bug)
1. run `curl -H "Accept:text/event-stream" 'http://localhost:5051/eth/v1/events?topics=attestation'`
2. wait a bit

**Expected behavior:** [What you expect to happen]
Stream continues until stopped.

**Actual behavior:** [What actually happens]
Stream is closed by Teku.

**Frequency:** [What percentage of the time does it occur?]

100%

### Additional Information

It seems to be working for me on MainNet.  My quick theory is that at some point attestations are received faster than they can be sent out to the event stream. Normally that's because the client reading from the stream is lagging behind and TCP back pressure builds up but could be thread contention on the server I guess.  Whatever causes is, Teku limits the number of pending events it will hold for a connection and if the limit is reached, the connection is closed.  Teku only logs a message at trace level when it does that.  Since a separate thread is publishing attestation events as fast as it can, the event above is triggered when it tries to publish the next one because the context is closed.

If that's right (which is definitely not a given), then the first log saying the queue is full should probably be more visible and the error because the context is closed should be bumped down to debug since it's entirely expected.  It also means this will be more likely to happen on Pyrmont with greater numbers of validators.

Reproduced this pretty easily with Pyrmont.   The maximum number of pending events is set to just 10 which is far too small for attestations.  Going to increase the default to about 250 which works with a local connection and make it a hidden config option in case there are use cases that needs to handle larger bursts.
